body:
>Alacritty shouldn't just let any shell program cause the icon to bounce, it should be the one in-control (and thus let the user choose).

We're just getting escapes, we don't know who is sending them etc, so it's nearly impossible to control things in the suggested way.

The question is whether we should allow disabling setting urgency flag on a window through the bell.

I personally don't mind adding something to toggle this kind of things, however I wonder who is responsible for silencing urgency requests in general. I think if you want to "disable icon jumping" for, let's say, `N` apps, you probably want to disable this behavior in one specific place (e.g. your WM settings), and not changing all application to fit your needs.

I also wondering about how other macOS terminal emulators behave in the mentioned use case (I don't have macOS machine to test things myself), but I feel like no one provides a toggle to alter this behavior (they're not setting urgency at all or setting it all the time like `alacritty`).

There are two escape sequences which already exist that Alacritty currently does not implement:
 - DEC 1042 -> Enable Urgency window manager hint on bell
 - DEC 1043 -> Enable raising of the window on bell

I'm copying the descriptions for these escapes below:

**`bellIsUrgent`**
> Ps = 1 0 4 2  ⇒  Enable Urgency window manager hint when Control-G is received, xterm. This enables the bellIsUrgent resource.
>
> bellIsUrgent (class BellIsUrgent)
Specifies whether to set the Urgency hint for the window manager when making a bell sound.  The default is "false".

**`popOnBell`**
> Ps = 1 0 4 3  ⇒  Enable raising of the window when Control-G is received, xterm.  This enables the popOnBell resource.
>
> popOnBell (class PopOnBell)
Specifies whether the window would be raised when Control-G is received.  The default is "false".
If the window is iconified, this has no effect.  However, the zIconBeep resource provides you with the ability to see which iconified windows have sounded a bell.

I'm mainly wondering how we should interpret "urgent" and "raising" for a window. Urgent to me (an i3 user) means that I can set my window to be outlined in red, I'd also think this maps to bouncing icons in the macOS dock. Raising a window, I'm less familiar with. Is this a way for an application to assert focus? [This](http://lists.lugod.org/pipermail/vox-tech/2007-November/013840.html) thread I found makes it seem like it is.

We currently, always send an `Urgent` event whenever a bell is received, so we could check the state of `bellIsUrgent` before sending this event.

https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/blob/679e67d045f60d528c695a1ee8a6c0f3d6feeda1/alacritty_terminal/src/term/mod.rs#L1502-L1506

The defaults for both, `bellIsUrgent` and `popOnBell` are false, making it seem like this issue would be resolved without extra configuration, and might break peoples expectations. Will users be aware of how to enable this?

> Urgent to me (an i3 user) means that I can set my window to be outlined in red, I'd also think this maps to bouncing icons in the macOS dock.

That is correct.

> Raising a window, I'm less familiar with. Is this a way for an application to assert focus? This thread I found makes it seem like it is.

Imagine having a thousand windows open, I think "raise" just means that no matter how "deep" below other windows it is, the application will be moved to the top of the stack to allow user interaction.

However, I mostly mentioned this for completeness sake. I don't think it's necessary for us to support this to finish this PR.

> We currently, always send an Urgent event whenever a bell is received, so we could check the state of bellIsUrgent before sending this event.

Yeah, I think that would be the best solution. It should be fairly straight-forward.

> The defaults for both, bellIsUrgent and popOnBell are false, making it seem like this issue would be resolved without extra configuration, and might break peoples expectations. Will users be aware of how to enable this?

We don't need to (and shouldn't imho) change the defaults. We would just add an option to disable it at runtime through an escape.
There's a lot of very specific stuff here. What's the summary? Is this something doable? I'd love to have a configuration to disable any kind of icon bouncing.

> There's a lot of very specific stuff here. What's the summary?

There's a standardized escape sequence and we just need to implement it.

> Is this something doable?

It is, given that someone has the time to implement it.
Another voice to the group who'd like to see this done - the behaviour is pretty annoying today :(
Hi @chrisduerr I think I can get this done. Can you assign this to me ?

@qrasmont one important note, is that this config option should be in a special section proposed [there](https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/issues/3386), so you'll likely implement infrastructure for this issue as well in your PR, however you don't have to add any additional OSCs(DEC) into it, besides the one for setting urgency.

@kchibisov  Ok since I'm new to the code base (and terminal emulators in general) I think what I had understood is not correct.

I taught supporting DEC 1042 would allows the user to enable/disable bell urgency at runtime.

But in fact DEC 1042  wouldn't be set by a user, it's just an escape sequence that could be received from any program and should be supported, allowing to define if the Urgent event should be send or not .

And the user can choose to never allow the bell to be urgent using the new config options you suggest in #3386 . Is that correct ?

>I taught supporting DEC 1042 would allows the user to enable/disable bell urgency at runtime.

This is correct, it could be triggered during runtime.

>But in fact DEC 1042 wouldn't be set by a user, it's just an escape sequence that could be received from any program and should be supported, allowing to define if the Urgent event should be send or not .

Yeah, but if you disable this escape(restrictions I'm talking in #3386) it should prevent urgent setting, and so we can don't set urgent if that setting was disabled by the user at all, leaving it enabled by default, and acting like it was enabled. Also, those escapes are pretty strange and unlikely are used.

>And the user can choose to never allow the bell to be urgent using the new config options you suggest in #3386 . Is that correct ?

Kind of, you can blacklist DEC 1042 in this options. However user could actually want to disable it and set resource to some value by default. So I feel like we should have a way to set default behavior for those escapes, what do you think @chrisduerr ? I feel like we need special syntax to describe each osc in a kind of unique way. Something like:

```yaml
escapes:
- { resource: UrgentOnBell, resource: enabled/disabled, toggle_with_escape: true/false }
```
I'm not sure where it should be an array, since you can't work with them generically, I also don't really like suggested naming, but it's just some idea, maybe we can have something like:
```yaml
- UrgentOnBell
  resource: enabled.
  toggle_with_escape: false
```

I'm really not sure what syntax should we use and how it should work together.

However you can at least implement DEC 1042 without those special option and any other config related option, since internal infrastructure to add this escape should be the same, regardless of new config options (e.g. toggling urgency, when we're getting this escape sequence).

If I'm following this correctly, the steps are perhaps:

1. Start implementing `CSI ? Pm l` (and possibly `CSI ? Pm h` as well)
2. Implement a way to disable "toggle with escape", or maybe "toggle with command sequence"

These could be two separate PRs as far as I'm concerned. Though the feature wouldn't necessarily be reliable without a way to set this statically, I agree.

I think you're needlessly over-complicating things.

All we need to do for now is implement the two escape sequences I've mentioned. These can then be set by users in their prompt or wherever they wish and that should solve this issue for most people.

I don't think many applications actively use this, so I don't see any requirements to implement escape sequence configuration for this.

@chrisduerr this is why I mentioned two separate PRs. Since I agree just two escape sequences are most likely to solve most peoples use cases.

However, a solution for the issue of toggling or configuring escape sequences (is there an open issue for this, I can't seem to find it) would of course be a nice addition, but much more complex of a feature.
Ok that certainly clears thing up, thanks everyone! I had already done the work for 1042 on to 1043 🛫
